comments.commentBody: I lived in Bologna and Milano for 8 years in the 90s and understand the Italian "modo da vivere" very well. The last time I visited, last Fall, I was somewhat saddened by the changes I found. Let's face it, we all have complained about Italy's penchant for doing things in a less organized way than we might like, but that has always been part of "la dolce vita". Now things have changed in a country where change comes SLOWLY. There is a resignation that the system will not provide the efficient means of government that is needed to remain relevant in this century, and that aside from fashion and sexy autos and food/wine, Italy is a country whose best years may have passed. That is a terrible burden to live under if you're a contemporary Italian and I fear that it is the mood that has now firmly taken hold and will last for some time to come. Alllora, adesso andiamo a mangiare una bella pizza?!
Republicans and their 'owners' are making it a much more painful step than it needs to be, but it is a step forward.

"...Republicans oppose healthcare reform precisely because they don't think healthy people should have to subsidize sick people."

I see a pattern developing here. I would suspect that Republicans oppose public education because childless homeowners and homeowner s whose children are beyond school age, have to subsidize schools for other people's children.

There is a growing conflict between the needs of the community and the needs of the individual. Yet both needs must be met and require individuals either voluntarily to support community goals, through their religious and ethical beliefs, by government coercion of one sort or another, or both.

Good point on the (lack of) control insurance has on costs. If insurance really controlled costs well, then why have laser eye surgery and cosmetic procedures costs have gone DOWN and the cost of an office or ER visit gone up? Shouldn't that be reversed because most policies limit coverage on eye survery and cosmetic procedures?

Mr. Douhat,

If having less insurance is so good at controlling costs, why do we spend so much more on healthcare than other countries? And if you say that this is a result of the fact that so many Americans lead unhealthy lifestyles, I would suggest that you consider the fact that perhaps our unhealthy lifestyles are a result of the fact that we visit doctors much less than people in other countries.

Do you really think that being "price sensitive" to the cost of seeing a doctor results in better health? Is that how it works in the rest of the world?

The reality is that the ACA represents an attempt to change paradigm of having insurers keep costs low by excluding sick people into one where they try to keep costs low by promoting good health practices and negotiating lower rates from hospitals. Or by being smarter in the way they pay for and manage treatment.

The reality is that Republicans oppose healthcare reform precisely because they don't think healthy people should have to subsidize sick people. I find that to be despicable and am tired of "thoughtful" conservatives attempting to justify it.

"Italy is what happens when a country knows full well what its problems are but can’t summon the discipline and will to fix them. It’s what happens when political dysfunction grinds on and on and good governance becomes a mirage, a myth, a joke. Italy coasts on its phenomenal blessings . . .. Sound familiar?"

Yes. Yes it does.

Mr. Bruni knows both Italy and the US so well that perhaps he can offer us some guide to how far along we are. What were Italy's waypoints to this, and how are we now in relation to the same waypoints?

I'd guess we've passed more of the same waypoints than we realized, and are closer to Italy than we'd ever imagined.

Not yet 2 years since I lost my husband of 21 years. As full-time RV travelers and dwellers for over 8 years, we depended heavily on one another for everything. We were best friends, intellectually equal and a vast majority of our interests were similar.

I wish Ms. Brozeck well, as I was in a like frame of mind not many months ago. It was an ugly place; second guessing and regretting every previous action. But, I, like many others like us, know it can get better and usually does.

This is the first time in my 63 years that I've actually lived solely on my own. And I love it.
Excellent, Mark. And you could have added one more question: More subsidized than Wall St. banks and giant multinationals on corporate welfare?
I don't think he was complaining about it being more subsidized. He pointed out that for many the government subsidies make the plans more affordable. Unless you meant something else.

So ... now, it's right that insurance is no longer a personal decision: government gets to set a standard and enforce it on individuals, and make many or even most pay for that arrogation of power, an insistence that an elite knows better than the individual how that individual should conduct his life.

Suggest you not go with that argument. If it develops legs among progressives, not only will you lose the Senate, but Republicans may take veto-proof majorities in BOTH houses.

Better to stick with improved access by the poor to subsidized insurance, which is all that anybody believed was the real objective of ObamaCare -- and, if they can get people signed up, it could actually secure that objective.

Then, your charge that "more expensive is a lie" is specious. Whether there are more insured or not, it remains that the total cost of healthcare will go up, and probably very substantially. The CURRENT total cost of government-subsidized healthcare is bankrupting us, or so warns the CBO. We don't effectively address that peril by INCREASING overall cost.

Finally, we began life as a people saying that what one earned was his; and, as we developed, we moderated that by saying, yes ... but we'll do what society can afford to do to ease inequalities in what people earn. Now, apparently according to Mark, so long as inequalities exist, what you earn ISN'T yours but is a public asset dedicated to erasing ALL inequalities.

Good luck selling that. Veto-proof Republican majorities.

His three mores: "Insurance à la Obamacare will be more expensive, more subsidized and more comprehensive than what was previously available."

One is a good thing, one is a lie, and one is a talking point like "socialism."

More comprehensive insurance is a good thing, a very good thing. Holes in ones insurance, in all of our insurance, are bad things.

More expensive is a lie. This bring down total costs per covered patient. The only increase is that many more Americans are covered. Only a Republican could see that as a bad thing. It is a lie to call it more expensive.

More subsidized is a talking point. More subsidized than Medicaid or Medicare? No. More subsidized than fully deductible employer contributions? No. More subsidized than the private insurance a few can buy but most must go without? Yes. Only a Republican could complain about that. Socialism! Why don't they just crawl off and die if they can't afford insurance? This is the USA, not USSR! Well, because it is the USA, and not just of Republican rich guys.

The concomitant enrichment of the overclass and collapse of the underclass speaks to a fundamental political failure in America. The times call for a political rupture, a renunciation of the old model and the old compromises.
Such rupture has occurred, of course, on the right with the rise of tea party populism, pseudo though that populism might be.
The Democrats need a similar rupture on the left. Environmentalists, unionists, the social sector, the poor, and the visible minorities need tell the Democrat establishment that politics as usual needs to end.
Obama was elected by lower-income Americans and has done precious little for them. The Democrat establishment is not shocked by the 23 per cent child poverty rate.
The left has to present a comprehensive program to the DNC on poverty, unionization, minimum wage, a new child benefit, universal childcare, expanded u.i., and higher taxes on the top 15 per cent. If Democrats will not support social and democratic renewal then they should face candidates from the left.

Companies have be incentivized to create life saving drugs, while at the same time, allowing them to be affordable to the public. Achieving both at the same time is the way to fix the problem -- no small feat of course when the drugs that save your life cost billions in research alone. So you must know that companies are not "bilking" in the sense that you describe. They are operating in the imperfect system we have. So why dont you offer some constructive criticism rather than painting various parties as good or evil.

The cause of America's out-of-control healthcare spending isn't that Americans are somehow addicted to excessive levels of medical care. It's that the various for-profit players in the system have learned how to bilk both individuals and the government to a fare-thee-well - and also that packaged and fast food executives have figured out that one of the easiest way to get rich is to convince Americans to eat food that can ultimately only make them sick.

Seriously, America's runaway health care expenditures are a reflection of an ethos that places profit above all other considerations - which is, after all, the gospel of the modern conservative movement.

Jim,
The top 1% pay 40% of the taxes because they are the only ones who have made any gains in the last decade!

And, you are comparing apples to oranges: they rates they pay are the lowest since the 1920's. There is no reason that wages are taxed at a far higher rate then capital; that preferencial rate for earned interest/capital gains is costing us as a nation dearly.

Taxes are to pay for things we cannot do alone -- they pay for civilization. Those who have the gold must pay the same rates that the rest of us do -- without our labor, there would be no gold for the 1%.

Jim: The 1% and its minions slyly restricts the conversation to income taxes, obscuring the fact that many of the 47% who pay none are still subject to payroll taxes which together account for as much Federal revenue as income tax. Obama should have hung tough and repealed the Bush tax cuts for everyone earning above $111,000, the point at which payroll taxes become regressive.
You need some broader international comparisons than debt to GDP ratios. OECD figures provide evidence of American exceptionalism, but not of the kind we should be proud of. We now have among the highest concentrations of wealth and the lowest rates of social mobility in the industrialized world. The size of our tax revenues relative to GNP is down there with Mexico and Turkey. The Republicans are right, or at least half right, about one thing: then NOMINAL corporate tax rates are too high. But the fact that 26 corporations paid their CEOs more than they paid in corporate taxes tells you something: there are so many loopholes that the ACTUAL amount of revenue collected relative to GNP puts us tied with Turkey for last place in the developed world. So we have the worst of both worlds: maximum distortion (if libertarian models are correct) producing minimum revenue.
And while we’re on international comparisons, only three other countries which are members of the OECD have a higher degree of income inequality than the U.S.: Chile, Mexico and Turkey. Do I detect a pattern here?

Mindless budget cutters are sure to claim parallels to the U.S., but the ailments of Italy, (dramatized by an NPR segment on tax dodging yacht owners) and particularly Greece and Spain, are less the alleged Democratic malady of runaway spending than the Republican malady of unwillingness, even by multimillionares, to pay more than 13 % taxes. An unbiased look across the European spectrum shows that Greece and Spain have public sectors not much larger than ours relative to GNP. Some of the healthiest economies currently are those with the largest public sectors: Scandinavians, Germans, Dutch; the biggest exception being Italy. But as one of our political satirists quipped, in order to keep our health care system from turning into Europe, the Republicans tried to turn our government into Italy.

Yes!  I remember being surprised and horrified after Obama's election that so many were so stingy that they wished to deny their fellow citizens the right and ability to have health coverage.  It's such a selfish attitude.  I still cannot fathom that mindset.  I thought we were better than that, truly.

There has never been a country that has achieved greatness by devaluing its currency. Devaluation rewards ineffective managers and politicians by making it appear that their economies are doing well. It masks the reduction of real income to those who must work to earn their livings. It increases the transfer of riches from the poor and middle class to the rich. It is a temporary means to steal business from other economically responsible countries.

Look at the countries whose economies are truly doing well and you will see that they have and have had strong currencies. Look at the countries not doing so well, and you will see that their currencies are weakening or have weakened.

Our problems predate the introduction of the euro, simply the lira prevented the possibility of their emergence. Most our problems are due to the anti-fascist organization of the state that aimed at preventing a single person to achieve total prominence, but that was so "efficient" to block any reform.

It is like a ship with the rudder blocked: until someone cleared the icebergs in front of us as it was during the Cold War, that was not a major problem. Now that the US quitted this operation without in any way contributing to the reactivation of the rudder, we tend to crash into them them on a daily basis!

While it is possible that Italian economy would now temporary benefit from a devalued currency, the issue is why it has been unable to take advantage from the euro in terms of lower interest rate on the public debt, lower costs of raw materials, energy etc. in the years before the crisis.
Even before the introduction of the euro, Italian economy was growing at a far slower pace than its competitors. The devaluation of the lira was the sole response of which an unaccountable leading class and a stuck institutional system were capable. It distorted the incentives and concealed the problems, acting like a dope.

It is possible that a number of the points made by Bruni are valid, but they have little to do with the problem that Italy faces now. The problem is the EURO. Italy's economy desperately needs to devalue its currency. But they can't, they don't control it. That is why they have "40 percent unemployment among young adults and an economy whose listlessness has come to seem the new normal", and nothing else.

I could go into more length, but there are more knowledgeable people available to the reader: Paul Krugman and Brad Delong are two. Search for articles written by them on this subject and learn what is actually happening.

The world has been in a depression for five years now, and the basic economic realities of our situation are still being ignored by the most everyone, including Frank Bruni. This is as unfortunate as it is astonishing.
